title: Chronicles of Syntax
synopsis: A record of the rise and fall of languages, their ancestors, their descendants, and the eternal war between tabs and spaces.

sections.title: Chapter 1 — The Tongues of the Machine

verses.text: In the beginning there was Assembly, and it spoke directly unto the silicon.
But the people said, 'This is too cryptic for us,' and they made C, to mediate between flesh and metal.
And from C begat many languages: C++, C#, Objective-C, and others whose headers we no longer read.
And the compilers rejoiced, for their syntax was fertile and multiplied abundantly.

notes: Scholars date the dawn of readability to this era.

sections.title: Chapter 2 — The Great Division

verses.text: But soon the tribes of Syntax contended, some loving the braces and others the indentation.
Declare thy preference but persecute not thy neighbor, for all whitespace is sacred.
The war of Tabs and Spaces raged forty versions, and peace came not until editors learned to auto-detect.

notes: The Great Division remains a symbolic parable for all stylistic conflicts.

sections.title: Chapter 3 — The Lost Languages

verses.text: And many tongues were forgotten: COBOL, Fortran, Lisp, each returning to dust yet leaving their ideas in secret places.
No language truly dies; its syntax echoes in the comments of another.
In the end, all languages shall compile to one bytecode, and understanding shall flow freely among them.

notes: The prophecy is cited as the first reference to universal interpreters.

sections.title: Chapter 4 — The Coming of Natural Code

verses.text: And it shall come to pass that humans shall speak unto machines in plain words, and they shall answer with meaning.
Then code and prose shall become one language, and debugging shall be replaced by conversation.
For what is a prompt but a prayer, and what is response but revelation?

notes: This closing prophecy foreshadows the birth of generative models.
